BE11:14am

Imperial Brands reported Tobacco and NGP net revenue growth of 3.9% (2.2% constant fx), ahead of consensus at 3.0%. Adjusted operating profit declined 0.5% (consensus +3.2%) principally owing to one-off NGP supply contract termination costs and inventory provisions as well as lower than anticipated other income. Adjusted EPS increased 0.4% to 273.3p (consensus 272p). Guidance is for both revenue (consensus +2.8%) and EPS (consensus +3.5%) to grow LSD reflecting more a conservative approach on NGP and a higher corporate tax rate of c.21%.
■ Tobacco net revenue increased 1.1% in constant currency, of which price mix accounted for 5.5%. In the US constant currency revenue increased 6.8%.Volumes declined only 2%, benefitting from trade loading and a welcome increase in cigarette market share of 10bps to 8.8%. Underlying cigarette volumes declined 5.3%, compared with 5.5% for the market. Europe tobacco net revenue increased 0.4%, of which 4.8% was price mix, with market shares generally lower. AAA constant currency revenue was down 4.8% (volume down 5%) driven by market declines in Russia, Australia and Middle East.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

NGP revenue of £285m was in line with recently reduced guidance. The company has announced that it has reprioritised NGP investment behind markets and categories where it sees the most upside, reflecting bigger uncertainty around the vaping category, particularly in the US, and, potentially, increased emphasis on heated tobacco and modern oral.
■ Asset disposals. The group has accounted for its Premium Cigar Division as a business held for disposal, suggesting that it is highly probable that its disposal will be completed. As a consequence, the value of this business has been impaired by £525m to £1.1bn, which would suggest disposal proceeds significantly ahead of our previous estimate of £600-700m. On disposal, the FY asset impairment will be significantly offset by anticipated cumulative foreign exchange gains of £300-400m. Imperial has further announced that owing to low current tobacco valuations, it does not intend to pursue further asset disposal at this stage. If Premium Cigars are disposed at its restated net book value, this will bring total non-core asset disposals to £1.4bn.

BE11:14am

No change in dividend policy. In line with previous guidance, the FY19 dividend was increased by 10%, with future dividend growth reflecting the underlying performance of the business.

Bluesky21 I think the JPM / banking angle is to sell the whole of Imperial Brands

BE11:18am

Imperial Brands FY19 missed on FY19 EPS (at 273p, 1% below Bloomberg consensus). While top line was a slight beat (+2.2% vs JPMe +2.0%), thanks to Tobacco, margin missed (41.6% vs consensus 42.3%) due to weaker profit in Europe. FY20 guidance of low single digit revenues and EPS at constant FX implies a 2-3% cut to FY20 consensus mainly related to higher tax rate. IMB is on track to submit PMTA before the May 2020 deadline. The company also announced the appointment of Therese Esperdy as Chairman, effective January 2020, as the board will look to appoint a replacement for CEO Alison Cooper. In light of Imperial shares underperformance (-27% YTD vs PMI +25%, BATS +11% and MO -4%), we would expect the shares to see some relief given the resilience of the combustible business, though we need more details on the drivers of NGP strategy in light of lower investments in 2020

Bluesky21 @nightinghale20201 - I feel I have to resort to cultural stereotyping here and talk about the Japanese tendency to overpay
11:18 am
BE11:19am

Management expect ‘low single digit revenue and earnings per share growth’ in FY20, ‘excluding any impact from the divestment programme’, and with performance expected to be H2 weighted as the benefit from the NGP reset takes effect through the year. Management indicate a reduction in FY20 NGP investment (though will scale up as visibility on returns and regulatory uncertainties improves), will roll out Pulze heated tobacco across Japan (increased production capacity and plans for further geographical expansion), and are focused on finalizing their PMTA application for blu in time for the May 2020 deadline. IMB to deliver £60m of cost optimization savings in FY20, concluding its £300m programme. IMB expects its FY20 effective adjusted tax rate to be ‘around 21%’ (up from 19.1% in FY19 owing to ‘legislative changes in several jurisdictions and the expiry of certain tax agreements’). The revised capital allocation policy supports a progressive dividend, growing annually and taking account of underlying business performance.

John Wood Group PLC (WG.:LSE): Last: 379.00, up 12.9 (+3.52%), High: 382.40, Low: 370.10, Volume: 874.11k

BE11:24am

Up to neutral.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

We upgrade Wood to Neutral from Sell post -c.20% sector-relative performance over the last 3 months. The shares are now trading on c.5x 2020E EV/EBITDA, below the 8x 10-year history. While we believe a discount to the long-term multiple is warranted given concerns around the Amec Foster Wheeler acquisition, we think the market is now pricing in these risks and see a value case emerging as a number of the issues post the deal have already played out. Our 12-month PT of 445p (unchanged) implies 32% upside, slightly below the average c.36% upside we have for European OFS, leaving us Neutral.

BE11:25am

Our key concerns were legacy contracts and the cash one-offs relating to these, as well as a slower de-gearing process. 2019 should be the peak for these one-off costs and Wood has announced a disposal to de-gear faster. The company has already highlighted a number of legacy contracts inherited from Amec FW on top of restructuring charges, but we expect these one-offs to decline significantly in 2020 (from $180m in 2019E to $60m in 2020E). In addition, with 1H19 results, Wood addressed balance sheet concerns by announcing the disposal of its nuclear business for $305m to Jacobs which would take 2020E ND/EBITDA to 1.4x (not in our estimates given the deal has not closed), below the targeted 1.5x.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Ah, here we are. Sector review.

andyalan10 Sorry to be late to the party but what could be more climate change friendly than growing plants that humans voluntarily use to kill themselves prematurely whilst also paying shedloads of tax that can be used in subsidies for wind/electric cars etc. Go IMB. Can I have a job in CSR or IR?
BE11:30am

The US onshore market slowdown is not ‘new news’ but we think the market thinks it is temporary for the US exposed European OFS names; we think the slowdown is structural and will continue into next year. We believe 2018 was the peak growth year for US shale as tighter financing conditions in the high yield market for new Oil & Gas investment, lower productivity gains and high decline rates indicate that the shale treadmill is slowing down (as we wrote in “Top Projects: The End of Non-OPEC Growth“). We expect the market will increasingly be dominated by the majors, which means the services names will have less pricing power than in the 2017/18 period which saw numerous smaller customers. While 2019 expectations have already largely been rebased, we still see downside risk to 2020E (we are -6% and -11% vs Bloomberg consensus 2020E EBITDA for Tenaris and Hunting, respectively) as the market still expects a better 2020 in US onshore spend.

BE11:30am

Our most exposed names to US onshore are Hunting, Tenaris and Vallourec. Hunting’s Titan business is largely exposed to US onshore and made up 45% of revenues in FY18 (but almost 80% of EBIT), selling perforating guns, setting tools and associated hardware. Both Tenaris and Vallourec sell OCTG to US onshore customers with Tenaris relatively more exposed, at almost 50% of its FY18 sales coming from North America while Vallourec had around a third.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

We downgrade Hunting to Sell from Neutral and reiterate our Sell on Tenaris; we remain Buy on Vallourec. We downgrade Hunting to Sell based on our concerns around the US onshore slowdown offsetting any recovery in international (we reduce our 12m PT to 385p from 602p on a lower target multiple reflecting our view that shares will continue to trade closer to the depressed 2014/15 levels when US onshore last slowed significantly). We reiterate our Sell on Tenaris (PT to €9.40 from €13; ADR US$20.6 from US$28.5) based on its exposure to the US onshore slowdown. We remain Buy on Vallourec on a recovery in international (to which it is more exposed) but reduce our PT to €3.30 from €4 to reflect US onshore risks.

BE11:31am

Merrill also dumping on Hunting this morning.

Bluesky21 Buying restructuring UK names based on faith in star CEOs has mainly been a losing strategy in the last few years
BE11:31am

Hunting faces cyclical & structural challenges: we reduce PO to 320p, reiterate U/P, see it trading on 7.5x EBITDA, 30x PE. Profit warning resets EBITDA expectations, but not low enough: we see c5% downside to FY19 guide, 30% downside to 20 cons. Flagship Titan (perf gun) business continues to over-earn: we see EBITDA margin dropping to 14% in 2021 (from more than 20% in 2019).

11:40 am
BE11:41am

And the switch to an asset-light franchise model, while potentially exciting and stuff, doesn't really get any new wind from today's update.

BE11:41am

It also draws obvious comparisons with WeWork, which were good comparisons right up to the moment that they weren't.

BE11:41am

Here's Stifel to summarise.

Bluesky21 I have always thought of IWG as an option on real estate prices - they price on current rent level to breakeven, they put the SPV in bankruptcy if rents go down, but if rents go up over time they make money
FATDAZ @bluesky largely depends on reasons why I and even more whether you can defend yourself against those factors
11:42 am
BE11:42am

Headline revenues were +9.4% at constant currency (vs +10.3% in 1H), inclusive of a 6.1% headwind from closures. Performance was driven by the Americas and EMEA, the group's two largest regions, and very encouraging contributions from the 2018 and 2019 centre additions.
Pre-2018 (mature) revenues were +3.3% (cc) in 3Q vs +5.2% in 1H19A. Encouragingly, the UK has started to contribute to pre-2018 revenue growth, showing actions taken to improve performance are having a positive impact. Pre-2018 occupancy improved 2.2%
to 76.4% in 3Q.
New centre openings - capex guidance increased. 66 new centres opened in 3Q with net growth capex of £64.4m. Total openings YTD are 180, around one-third through
partnering, including the opening of 82 Spaces. Visibility for the full year is net growth capex of £280m on 260 locations and 7.5m sq ft of space, higher than prior guidance of
net growth capex of £260m on 250 locations and 7.0m sq ft of space.
Network rationalisation. The group has rationalised c.4% of the network in the nine months to 30 September 2019. This impacts near-term profitability (by £27.9m YTD), but will deliver improved returns and value creation in the future. This focus is expected to continue in 4Q19 and early 2020.
Progress on franchising. Following the master franchise agreements in Japan, Taiwan and Switzerland, in total the group has 27 franchise partners across 22 countries, with combined commitments of over 400 new centre locations. The group anticipates reporting on further deals in the future to continue to unlock value for shareholders.
Group net debt at 30 September on a pre-IFRS 16 basis was £301.2m (vs £298.1m at 1H), representing leverage of 0.8x, the lower-end of the 0.75x-1.5x target range.
Outlook. The group remains very confident in the structural, long-term growth in the flexible workspace market and IWG's leading place within it. The group continues to invest in its leading global platform and management to support the strategy and looks forward to the rest of the year with confidence.

BE11:43am

They're pro.

BE11:43am

Momentum continues to build in franchising, as highlighted by the Switzerland deal announced yesterday. The group has closed c.4% of the network YTD being a c.£28m headwind to profitability, and we expect these closures to reduce FY19E consensus operating profit by c.10%. Despite this, we continue to view IWG as an attractive investment proposition and believe the further franchising deals, such as the agreement in Switzerland announced yesterday, have the potential to transform investors' perception of value.

Bluesky21 Is IWG franchising just a bet on the continuing abundance of cheap (and dumb) capital then?
11:43 am
BE11:43am

And a few conference call notes from Credit Suisse:

Confident overview from the management team. Good momentum in the underlying business despite the costs (which are typically non-cash) of the rationalistion program. This program will continue into H120. More M&A opportunities arising in current markets. Franchise pipeline remains busy and are looking to announce a “steady stream” of deals over the next 12 months.

Bluesky21 Because, if you are any good as a landlord, once you have built up a tenant base you really don't need IWG
BE11:44am

See potential for more consolidation in the coming years. Many of the smaller operators do not have the economies of scale to be profitable and that is leading to more competitors facing significant economic challenges. See more rational pricing from WeWork in recent weeks. IWG expects to benefit, from a demand perspective, in the coming months.

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:46am

IWG is growing the occupancy in its mature estate and delivering on its opening programme. Closures of centres though are hitting profit more than we had expected. Coupled with the impact of the (value-enhancing) sale of the Swiss business, we reduce continuing PBT by 13% for this year and 6% next. Our target price moves down slightly, from 500p to 480p, to reflect it, but the bigger driver is the potential of the move to a franchise model which brings good momentum.

Oaktree Urges Board to Postpone Court Sanction Hearing Date Pending Spectrum Approval or Provide Shareholders with a Contingent Value Right to Reflect Significant Potential Additional Value

tangledodyssey Bilious as well as bileful.
BE11:52am

Funds and accounts managed by Oaktree Capital Management, L.P. (collectively, “Oaktree”), a 2.85% shareholder in Inmarsat PLC (“Inmarsat”), sent a letter to the Inmarsat Board of Directors on November 5, 2019.

In its letter, Oaktree urges the Inmarsat Board to postpone the Court Sanction Hearing, currently scheduled for November 12^th, in order to allow the U.S. regulatory approval process for Inmarsat’s valuable Ligado spectrum assets to conclude. Alternatively, Oaktree asks the Board to negotiate for contingent value rights or another mechanism that will allow shareholders to participate in the significant potential value of Ligado’s spectrum assets. Oaktree believes the Takeover Offer that the Board of Inmarsat recommended to shareholders earlier this year ascribes no value to these crucial spectrum
assets and the associated lease for use in developing a 5G network, which in light of recent developments may be approved by the FCC in the near term.

The Board confirms that it is aware of the recent commentary regarding the potential Ligado Licence Modification.

The Inmarsat Board is mindful of its fiduciary duties and continues to monitor any developments regarding Ligado. In that context, the Board and its financial advisors have continued to properly assess, amongst other matters, the timing and prospect of revenue or other value to be received by Inmarsat pursuant to the cooperation agreement (between Inmarsat and Ligado) and in the Board's view, these remain uncertain. The Board considers that there has been no material change since it recommended the Acquisition and therefore intends to maintain the Scheme sanction hearing scheduled for 12th November 2019.

Unless otherwise defined, all capitalised terms in this announcement shall have the meaning given to them in the Scheme Document.

UBS:

Punter @1st, second your point about bean counters and intangibles
BE12:12pm

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Revenue was slightly below UBSe but broadly in line with cons. Adj PBT was a 2% beat. Adj EPS of 137.5p was 2% ahead of UBSe and comments at the pre-close for flat EPS yoy. Net cash was £936m, slightly above company guidance of ~£900m.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: 1) Grocery margin beat cons and UBSe at 10.8% (UBSe 10.2%, cons 10.1%); 2) Primark margin was a 10bps beat at 11.7% (UBSe 11.6%).
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Yes. Primark margin is now expected to only decline slightly next year (UBSe 11.1%).
Mgmt expects another year of 'strong profit growth' in Grocery (UBSe +10.1%) and continues to expect an improvement in AB Sugar profits from higher pricing.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: More positive outlook for Primark margin could be received positively, but the shares have run well going into the results (+9% over last four weeks).

12:14 pm
BE12:14pm

ABF issued a fairly detailed pre-close update in September, so it was always unlikely that today's prelims would contain much in the way of 'fireworks'. Indeed they do not. Full-year adjusted Pre Tax Profits have come in at £1,406m, compared with a consensus expectation (per Bloomberg) of £1,377m.- At the divisional level results are very much as we anticipated, with strong profit at Primark (up from £843m last year to £913m this year) offset by a sharp decline in the profit in the Sugar division (profits down from £123m last year to just £26m this year).- On first read, there doesn't appear to be much 'new news' on strategy, or on current trading. The comments on Primark's margins in the year ahead, however, appear to be a little more positive than those made in September, with management now expecting only a "small reduction" on the margins achieved in FY 2018/19.- This statement gives qualitative earnings guidance for FY 2019/20 for the first time, with "progress" expected in adjusted EPS, on both a reported and an IFRS 16 adjusted basis. We have yet to speak to the company this morning, but we would have thought that this qualitative guidance would be broadly consistent with current consensus expectations of c6% EPS growth in the year ahead. So we would not anticipate consensus forecasts changing much today, though there could be some modest upgrades (c1-2%) on the back of the revised comments about Primarks margins.- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, ABF is trading on 15.2x Cal 2020 earnings, 7.6x EBITDA with a 2.3% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 14.2x, 8.8x and 3.1% respectively.

BE12:16pm

Here's Canaccord.

BE12:17pm

This report, published without consultation with the industry regulator, the UK Gambling Commission (UKGC), called for a number of changes to reduce player harm, the most significant of these being the introduction of deposit and stake limits on online casino games (slots and blackjack/roulette). The last analysis of staking behaviour was undertaken by the University of Liverpool, which analysed data from January 2017 and showed that 92.8% of slots stake size was at £2 or less and that 66.9% of non-slots (i.e. blackjack/roulette) stakes was at £2 or less. Given the change in player bases over the last almost three years, with a significant reduction in VIP and high value player accounts, in part brought on by regulatory enforcement actions, we believe that the percentages of stakes at £2 or less to be even higher today.
Furthermore, an arbitrary deposit and stakes limit does very little to protect players, in our view. The breadth and depth of historic information held by gambling companies combined with real-time data provides numerous opportunities for highly targeted interventions to individual customer accounts when those players display markers of harmful gambling. The industry must to do better to communicate, and demonstrate, this to lawmakers.

BarristerM Who do I return the rubik's cube and fastFT stressball prizes I won if they turn out to be faulty now BE? Effing counterparty risk.
12:17 pm
BE12:18pm

We think there is minimal risk to any meaningful deposit and stakes limits being introduced over our forecast periods. The recent increase in remote gaming duty was designed to offset the reduction in tax revenue from the reduction in maximum stakes on land-based B2 content (FOBTs) to £2. It is hard to see how tax revenue from a reduction in online stakes could be replaced. If the government were prepared to look past this, we think the companies themselves are well placed to mitigate much of the financial impact through increased customer recycling, changes in return to player percentages and reductions in marketing spend (which is fundamentally ROI driven).
However, from an APPG objective, the likelihood is that none of this reduces player harm.
Those players that want to stake higher amounts will simply migrate to unlicenced, offshore sites with all the potential risks that entails. What has gone unreported is that the UKGC's latest data shows a statistically significant decline in moderate risk gambling rates from 1.7% to 1.1% for the year to September 2019 and static problem gambling rates at 0.5%; that does not suggest an industry in need of greater regulation.
Yesterday's share price falls (888: -13.7%, William Hill: -12.7% and Gamesys: -8.9% being the most material in our coverage universe) were significantly overdone in our view and we strongly reiterate our Buy recommendations on 888 Holdings, Gamesys Group and William Hill. We reiterate our Hold recommendations on Rank Group and The Stars Group.
